hints: A global system of interconnected computer networks.
Developed in the 1960s by the US government.
The foundation of the World Wide Web.
A mobile phone that performs many of the functions of a computer.
The first one was arguably the IBM Simon Personal Communicator.
Combines a cellular phone with a mobile operating system.
A family of wireless network protocols.
Allows devices to connect to the internet or communicate with each other.
Invented in 1991 by NCR Corporation/AT&T.
A satellite-based navigation system.
Owned by the US government and operated by the Space Force.
Originally known as Navstar.
An electronic circuit on a small piece of semiconductor material.
Also known as an integrated circuit.
Invented independently by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce in the late 1950s.
A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances.
Named after a 10th-century Scandinavian king.
Used for connecting headsets, speakers, and other peripherals.
A method of exchanging digital messages.
Ray Tomlinson is credited with its invention in 1971.
Uses the '@' symbol to separate username and domain.
An information space where documents and other web resources are identified by URLs.
Created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Often confused with the internet itself.
A device that captures photographs and stores them as digital data.
The first one was invented by Steven Sasson at Eastman Kodak in 1975.
Replaced traditional film cameras for most uses.
An early computer animation system.
Developed at MIT by Ivan Sutherland in 1963.
It used a light pen to draw on a computer screen.
A system for transmitting and receiving moving images and sound.
Philo Farnsworth and Vladimir Zworykin are key inventors.
First commercially available in the 1930s.
The technology of using radio waves to carry information.
Guglielmo Marconi is a key figure in its development.
First used for communication in the late 19th century.
A device for applying pressure to an inked surface.
Johannes Gutenberg's invention from the 15th century.
Made books and other texts widely accessible.
A heat engine that performs mechanical work using steam.
Crucial for the Industrial Revolution.
James Watt's improvements were significant.
A device that converts sound into electrical signals.
Alexander Graham Bell is widely credited as the inventor.
First patented in 1876.
A device that produces light from electricity.
Thomas Edison is famous for developing a practical version.
Used a glowing filament inside a glass bulb.
An appliance for keeping food and drinks cold.
Invented by Carl von Linde in 1876.
Utilizes a cooling system to preserve food.
A system that conditions the air in a space.
Invented by Willis Carrier in 1902.
Controls temperature and humidity.
An oven that heats food using electromagnetic radiation.
Invented by Percy Spencer in 1945.
Uses a magnetron to produce the waves.
A visual representation of data readable by a machine.
Invented by Norman Joseph Woodland and Bernard Silver.
First used to track groceries in a supermarket.
A semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals.
Invented by John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley.
A fundamental building block of modern electronics.
Stands for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation.
The first one was built by Theodore Maiman in 1960.
Used in everything from surgery to data storage.
A compact disc that contains data.
Invented by James Russell.
Stands for 'Compact Disc Read-Only Memory'.
A type of data storage device composed of a thin and flexible disk.
Invented by Alan Shugart at IBM.
Commonly came in 8-inch, 5.25-inch, and 3.5-inch sizes.
A semiconductor light source that emits light when current flows through it.
Stands for 'Light-Emitting Diode'.
Invented by Nick Holonyak Jr. in 1962.
A type of rechargeable battery.
Developed by John Goodenough, M. Stanley Whittingham, and Akira Yoshino.
Commonly used in smartphones and electric vehicles.
A device that records and plays back video on tape.
Stands for 'Video Cassette Recorder'.
Popular for home movie viewing before DVDs.
A device used to transmit scanned printed material.
The first commercial version was developed by Elisha Gray.
Sent documents over telephone lines.
A device that modulates and demodulates data signals.
Enables computers to communicate over telephone lines.
Stands for 'Modulator-Demodulator'.
A satellite-based navigation system.
Owned by the US government and operated by the Space Force.
Originally known as Navstar.
A machine that creates three-dimensional objects from a digital file.
The first one was developed by Chuck Hull in the 1980s.
Uses an additive manufacturing process.
A boat propelled by a steam engine.
Developed in the late 18th century.
Robert Fulton's Clermont was famous for commercial use.
A machine that stitches material together with thread.
Invented by Elias Howe in 1846.
Isaac Singer made significant improvements and popularized it.
A self-propelled road vehicle.
Carl Benz is credited with creating the first practical one.
The Ford Model T made it widely accessible.
An explosive made of nitroglycerin.
Invented by Alfred Nobel in 1867.
Was safer to handle than other explosives of the time.
A form of electromagnetic radiation.
Discovered by Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen in 1895.
Used to see through objects, especially in medicine.
A type of engine that expels a high-velocity jet of fluid.
Independently invented by Frank Whittle and Hans von Ohain.
Revolutionized air travel.
A vehicle designed for agricultural tasks.
John Froelich is considered the inventor of the first gas-powered one.
A major invention of the Green Revolution.
A guitar that uses a pickup to convert vibrations into electrical signals.
The first successful one was designed by George Beauchamp.
Used in rock and roll music.
A wireless telecommunications device.
Also known as a beeper.
Invented by Al Gross in 1949.
A material that has an electrical conductivity between a conductor and an insulator.
The foundation of modern electronics.
Silicon and germanium are common examples.
A transducer that converts sound into an electrical signal.
Invented by Emile Berliner in 1877.
Used in telephones, radios, and music recording.
A device for the mechanical recording and reproduction of sound.
Invented by Thomas Edison in 1877.
First used with tinfoil cylinders.
An electrical machine that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.
Invented in the early 19th century.
Used in countless appliances and machines.
An appliance that uses an air pump to create a partial vacuum.
First patented by Hubert Cecil Booth in 1901.
Used to clean floors and other surfaces.
An optical instrument that uses lenses to view distant objects.
Hans Lippershey is often credited with its invention.
Galileo Galilei was one of the first to use it for astronomy.
A navigational instrument that shows direction.
Invented in ancient China.
Uses a magnetized needle that aligns with the Earth's magnetic field.
A board with copper lines that connects electronic components.
Invented by Paul Eisler in 1936.
The foundation of modern electronic devices.
An electronic test instrument that graphically displays electrical signals.
Invented by Karl Ferdinand Braun in 1897.
Used for viewing voltage waveforms.
An electronic musical instrument that generates audio signals.
Invented by Robert Moog and others in the 1960s.
Can imitate other instruments or generate new sounds.
A technology that uses glass or plastic fibers to transmit data.
Invented by Charles K. Kao in the 1960s.
Used in high-speed internet and telecommunications.
A flat-panel display technology.
Stands for 'Liquid Crystal Display'.
Invented by George Heilmeier at RCA in the 1960s.
A type of display technology.
Stands for 'Organic Light-Emitting Diode'.
Used in high-end smartphones and TVs.
A type of display technology that mimics the appearance of ink on paper.
Stands for 'Electronic Ink'.
Used in devices like the Amazon Kindle.
A portable, battery-powered light source.
Invented by Joshua Lionel Cowen in 1898.
Also known as a torch.
A device that measures temperature.
Galileo Galilei invented an early version.
Fahrenheit and Celsius are common scales.
A small electric appliance used for toasting bread.
Invented by Alan MacMasters in 1893.
The pop-up version was invented by Charles Strite.
A device for recording and playing back audio.
Invented by Valdemar Poulsen in 1898.
The first commercial version was the German Magnetophon.
A pen that dispenses ink over a metal ball.
Invented by Laszlo Biro in 1938.
Popular for its reliability and convenience.
An electronic device used to perform arithmetic operations.
Blaise Pascal invented an early mechanical version.
The first pocket-sized one was the Canon Pocketronic.
A manual calculating device.
Used for centuries in various cultures.
Consists of beads on rods.
A mechanical analog computer.
Used primarily for multiplication and division.
Popular with engineers and scientists before calculators.
A device used to weave cloth.
The Jacquard version used punch cards to control patterns.
A key invention of the Industrial Revolution.
A rubber tire filled with compressed air.
Invented by John Boyd Dunlop in 1888.
Made for a smoother ride on bicycles and automobiles.
A moving staircase.
Invented by Jesse W. Reno in 1892.
Used in department stores, airports, and subways.
An instrument that records the motion of the ground during an earthquake.
Invented by Zhang Heng in ancient China.
Modern versions use electronic sensors.
A boat propelled by a steam engine.
Developed in the late 18th century.
Robert Fulton's Clermont was famous for commercial use.

Invented by Zhang Heng in ancient China.
Modern versions use electronic sensors.
A device that extracts thermal energy from pressurized steam.
Invented by Sir Charles Parsons in 1884.
Used to generate electricity in power plants.
An electric motor powered by alternating current.
Invented by Nikola Tesla in 1887.
Used in many household appliances and industrial machines.
A scientific instrument used to measure atmospheric pressure.
Invented by Evangelista Torricelli in 1643.
Used to forecast weather changes.
A firearm with a rotating cylinder of multiple chambers.
Invented by Samuel Colt in 1836.
Popularized for its rapid-firing capability.
A type of rifle that can fire multiple shots without reloading.
The Winchester brand is a famous example.
Revolutionized battlefield tactics.
A device used for capital punishment.
Invented by Harold P. Brown and Arthur Kennelly.
Used as a method of execution in the US.
A timepiece powered by a wound spring.
Peter Henlein is credited with inventing the first one.
Used to tell time before quartz movements.
An internal combustion engine that uses compression ignition.
Invented by Rudolf Diesel in 1892.
Known for its fuel efficiency and torque.
A shaving device with a rotating or oscillating blade.
Invented by Jacob Schick in 1928.
Allows for dry shaving without soap or water.
A cardboard box used to package breakfast cereal.
Invented by Kellogg's in the 1890s.
Led to the popularization of ready-to-eat cereals.
A machine for cleaning dishes and other kitchenware.
Invented by Josephine Cochrane in 1886.
Originally hand-cranked and used a motor.
A machine for washing laundry.
Invented in the late 18th and 19th centuries.
The electric version became common in the early 20th century.
An appliance used to remove moisture from clothes.
Invented by M. Pochon in France in the early 19th century.
The first electric one was invented by J. Ross Moore.
A machine for making paper copies of documents and other visual images.
Invented by Chester Carlson in 1938.
Also known as a xerographic machine.
A microscope that uses a beam of electrons to create an image.
Invented by Max Knoll and Ernst Ruska in 1931.
Can magnify objects much more than a light microscope.
A lamp that uses fluorescence to produce visible light.
Invented by Peter Cooper Hewitt in 1901.
More energy efficient than incandescent bulbs.
An explosive weapon that derives its destructive power from nuclear fission.
Developed during the Manhattan Project.
Used in World War II against Japan.
A camera that can develop and print photographs instantly.
Invented by Edwin Land in 1947.
Popular for its convenience and unique aesthetic.
A platform or cage for moving people or freight vertically.
Elisha Otis invented a safety brake for it.
Made skyscrapers possible.
A device for fastening two edges of fabric.
Invented by Whitcomb L. Judson in 1891.
The name was coined by B.F. Goodrich.
A flexible bag filled with gas.
The Montgolfier brothers created the first hot-air version.
Used for flight and meteorological studies.

Invented by Zhang Heng in ancient China.

Invented by Whitcomb L. Judson in 1891.
The name was coined by B.F. Goodrich.
A flexible bag filled with gas.
The Montgolfier brothers created the first hot-air version.
Used for flight and meteorological studies.
An astronomical instrument consisting of a large dish.
Used to detect radio waves from celestial objects.
Karl Guthe Jansky is considered the father of radio astronomy.
An electronic device that outputs a video signal to display a video game.
The Magnavox Odyssey was the first commercial one.
Nintendo, Sega, and Sony are famous manufacturers.
A flat panel display technology.
Replaced Cathode Ray Tubes (CRTs) in many applications.
Found in many monitors, televisions, and watches.
A small, portable data storage device.
Also known as a thumb drive or jump drive.
Replaced floppy disks and CD-Rs for portable storage.
A portable electronic device for reading books and periodicals.
The Amazon Kindle is a famous example.
Uses E-Ink technology.
Eyewear used to view stereoscopic 3D images.
First invented by Charles Wheatstone in 1838.
The anaglyph version uses red and blue lenses.
A mobile phone that has a built-in digital camera.
The first one was the Kyocera VP-210 in Japan.
Now a standard feature on almost all smartphones.
A line of portable media players.
Invented by Apple in 2001.
Revolutionized how people listen to music.
A digital optical disc storage format.
Stands for 'Digital Versatile Disc'.
Replaced the VCR as the standard for home movie playback.
A digital optical disc format used for high-definition video.
Named for the blue laser used to read the disc.
Competed with HD DVD in the 2000s.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
The Sensorama was an early example.
Requires a headset to fully immerse the user.
An interactive experience of a real-world environment.
Often used in mobile games like Pokémon Go.
Overlays digital information onto the real world.
An unmanned aerial vehicle.
Can be used for military, commercial, or recreational purposes.
Controlled remotely by a pilot.
A mobile computer with a touch screen.
The Apple iPad popularized the concept in 2010.
Larger than a smartphone but smaller than a laptop.
Electronic devices that can be worn as accessories.
Examples include smartwatches and fitness trackers.
Often used to monitor health and activity.
A portable computer worn on the wrist.
Can tell time, but also has a range of other functions.
The Pebble and Apple Watch are famous examples.
The process of determining the order of nucleotides in DNA.
Frederick Sanger developed a key method in 1977.
Led to the Human Genome Project.
A prosthetic device that replaces the heart.
The first successful implant was in 1982.
The Jarvik-7 is a well-known example.
A medical imaging technique.
Stands for 'Magnetic Resonance Imaging'.
Uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to create images.
A medical imaging technique that uses X-rays.
Invented by Sir Godfrey Hounsfield in 1972.
Stands for 'Computerized Axial Tomography'.
A medical device that delivers electrical impulses to the heart.
The first fully implantable one was created by Wilson Greatbatch.
Helps regulate an irregular heartbeat.
A medical imaging technique that uses sound waves.
Commonly used to view a fetus in the womb.
Also known as sonography.
A type of refractive surgery for correcting vision.
Uses a laser to reshape the cornea.
Stands for 'Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis'.
A machine capable of carrying out a complex series of actions.
The first one was the Unimate, designed for manufacturing.
Named after a Czech word for 'forced labor'.
A branch of computer science focused on creating intelligent machines.
Stands for 'Artificial Intelligence'.
John McCarthy is considered a founding father.
A computer system inspired by the human brain.
Used in machine learning for tasks like image recognition.
Consists of interconnected nodes or 'neurons'.

A branch of computer science focused on creating intelligent machines.
Stands for 'Artificial Intelligence'.
John McCarthy is considered a founding father.
A computer system inspired by the human brain.
Used in machine learning for tasks like image recognition.
Consists of interconnected nodes or 'neurons'.
A system for transmitting messages over a wire.
Samuel Morse developed a code for it.
Revolutionized long-distance communication in the 19th century.
A type of computer that uses physical phenomena.
The Antikythera mechanism is an ancient example.
Uses continuously varying values, not discrete numbers.
A type of computer that performs calculations using binary digits.
The ENIAC was one of the first.
The foundation of all modern computers.
A network of remote servers hosted on the internet.
Used to store, manage, and process data.
This is a metaphor for the internet.
A mobile phone that performs many of the functions of a computer.
The first one was arguably the IBM Simon Personal Communicator.
Combines a cellular phone with a mobile operating system.
A method of exchanging digital messages.
Ray Tomlinson is credited with its invention in 1971.
Uses the '@' symbol to separate username and domain.
A satellite-based navigation system.
Owned by the US government and operated by the Space Force.
Originally known as Navstar.
An electronic circuit on a small piece of semiconductor material.
Also known as an integrated circuit.
Invented independently by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce in the late 1950s.
A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances.
Named after a 10th-century Scandinavian king.
Used for connecting headsets, speakers, and other peripherals.
An information space where documents and other web resources are identified by URLs.
Created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Often confused with the internet itself.
A computer system that emulates another computer.
Allows a single computer to run multiple operating systems.
Used extensively in cloud computing and software development.
A type of computer that uses quantum-mechanical phenomena.
Can solve certain problems much faster than classical computers.
Relies on qubits instead of bits.
A computer with a high-level computational capacity.
Used for scientific research and complex simulations.
The Cray-1 was a famous example.
A large, powerful computer used for business and scientific computing.
Known for its reliability and high processing speeds.
IBM is a major manufacturer.
A computer program or device that provides functionality for other programs or devices.
Serves data to other computers on a network.
Houses websites and other online services.
One of the first electronic general-purpose computers.
Stands for 'Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer'.
Used to calculate artillery firing tables for the US Army.
A line of electronic digital stored-program computers.
Stands for 'Universal Automatic Computer'.
The first commercial computer produced in the US.
The first wide-area packet-switching network.
Predecessor to the modern internet.
Developed by the US Department of Defense.
A family of computer networking technologies for local area networks (LANs).
Invented by Robert Metcalfe in 1973.
Uses cables to connect computers in a network.
The foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web.
Stands for 'Hypertext Transfer Protocol'.
Used by browsers to request web pages from servers.
A set of communication protocols for the internet.
Stands for 'Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol'.
The fundamental protocols of the internet.
A system of interlinked hypertext documents accessed via the Internet.
Created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
The most popular part of the internet.
A type of interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons.
Stands for 'Graphical User Interface'.
Invented at Xerox PARC and popularized by Apple.
A pointing device that detects two-dimensional motion.
Invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964.
A key component of the graphical user interface.
A device for inputting text and characters into a computer.
Christopher Latham Sholes invented the QWERTY layout.
Has been in use for over a century, originally for typewriters.
A data storage device that uses magnetic platters.
Invented by IBM in 1956.
Commonly used for long-term data storage in computers.
A form of computer memory that can be read and changed in any order.
Stands for 'Random-Access Memory'.
Holds data currently being used by the operating system.
The electronic circuitry that carries out the instructions of a computer program.
Stands for 'Central Processing Unit'.
The 'brain' of the computer.
The main printed circuit board in a computer.
Connects all the components of a computer.
Also known as a mainboard or logic board.
A circuit board that generates output images to a display.
Also known as a graphics card.
Crucial for video games and professional graphics.
A video camera that feeds its images to a computer or computer network.
The first one was invented at the University of Cambridge.
Used for video conferencing and streaming.
Graphics that use a three-dimensional representation of geometric data.
Used in video games and computer animation.
Pioneered by Ivan Sutherland and others in the 1960s.
A display that can detect the presence and location of a touch.
Invented by E.A. Johnson in the 1960s.
Popularized by smartphones and tablets.
The ability of a machine or program to identify words and phrases.
A key component of virtual assistants like Siri and Alexa.
Pioneered by Bell Labs in the 1950s.
A cable containing one or more optical fibers.
Used for high-speed data transmission.
Transmits information using light pulses.
A wireless headset that connects to a device.
Uses a short-range wireless technology.
Allows for hands-free communication.
A television set with integrated internet and interactive features.
Can access streaming services like Netflix and Hulu.
Essentially a computer and a television in one device.
A head-mounted device that provides a virtual reality experience.
The Oculus Rift and HTC Vive are well-known examples.
Creates a completely immersive visual experience.
A device that analyzes a real-world object to collect data on its shape.
Creates a digital 3D model of the object.
Used for reverse engineering and quality control.
An autonomous vehicle capable of sensing its environment and navigating without human input.
Uses a variety of sensors like radar and cameras.
Tesla, Waymo, and Cruise are major players in this field.
An unmanned aerial vehicle.
Can be used for military, commercial, or recreational purposes.
Controlled remotely by a pilot.
The process of determining the order of nucleotides in DNA.
Frederick Sanger developed a key method in 1977.
Led to the Human Genome Project.
A prosthetic device that replaces the heart.
The first successful implant was in 1982.
The Jarvik-7 is a well-known example.
A medical imaging technique.
Stands for 'Magnetic Resonance Imaging'.
Uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to create images.
A medical imaging technique that uses X-rays.
Invented by Sir Godfrey Hounsfield in 1972.
Stands for 'Computerized Axial Tomography'.
A medical device that delivers electrical impulses to the heart.
The first fully implantable one was created by Wilson Greatbatch.
Helps regulate an irregular heartbeat.
A medical imaging technique that uses sound waves.
Commonly used to view a fetus in the womb.
Also known as sonography.
A type of refractive surgery for correcting vision.
Uses a laser to reshape the cornea.
Stands for 'Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis'.
A machine capable of carrying out a complex series of actions.
The first one was the Unimate, designed for manufacturing.
Named after a Czech word for 'forced labor'.
A branch of computer science focused on creating intelligent machines.
Stands for 'Artificial Intelligence'.
John McCarthy is considered a founding father.
A computer system inspired by the human brain.
Used in machine learning for tasks like image recognition.
Consists of interconnected nodes or 'neurons'.
A distributed, decentralized public ledger.
The underlying technology behind Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.
A key invention in digital trust and security.
A digital or virtual currency that is secured by cryptography.
Bitcoin was the first and most well-known.
Operates independently of a central bank.
A self-executing contract with the terms of the agreement directly written into code.
Runs on a blockchain.
Automates the execution of agreements.
The buying and selling of goods or services using the internet.
Amazon and eBay are pioneers in this field.
Revolutionized retail and shopping.
A platform for building social relations among people who share interests.
Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram are prominent examples.
A major force in modern communication and culture.
A discussion or informational website published on the World Wide Web.
A shortened form of 'weblog'.
Used for personal journals, news, and commentary.
A free, multilingual, open-source encyclopedia.
Founded by Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger in 2001.
A famous example of a wiki.
A software system designed to carry out web searches.
Google is the most famous example.
Helps users find information on the internet.
A portable digital device that stores and plays audio files.
The iPod popularized this type of device.
Replaced the Walkman and CD player for many.
An electronic device that records video in a digital format.
The TiVo was a famous early example.
Replaced VCRs for recording TV shows.
An electronic device that records video in a digital format.
Stands for 'Digital Video Recorder'.
The TiVo was a famous early example.
A setting on a digital display that reduces the amount of blue light emitted.
Designed to reduce eye strain and improve sleep.
Common on smartphones and computers.
A two-dimensional bar code.
Stands for 'Quick Response Code'.
Can be scanned by a smartphone camera to access information.
A system of broadcasting television programs to subscribers.
Uses coaxial or fiber optic cables.
Developed in the late 1940s.
A system of television broadcasting that uses satellites.
Requires a dish antenna to receive the signal.
Used in remote areas where cable is not available.
A watch that uses GPS technology to track location.
Used by runners, hikers, and other athletes.
Can also track speed, distance, and altitude.
A device for monitoring and tracking fitness-related metrics.
Counts steps, calories burned, and monitors heart rate.
The Fitbit is a famous example.
A wireless speaker with an integrated virtual assistant.
The Amazon Echo and Google Home are popular examples.
Can play music, answer questions, and control smart home devices.
A home that uses internet-connected devices to enable the remote monitoring and management of appliances.
Can control lighting, thermostats, and security systems.
A key component of the Internet of Things.
The network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies.
Stands for 'Internet of Things'.
Allows devices to collect and exchange data.
The on-demand availability of computer system resources.
Examples include Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud.
Allows for data storage and processing over the internet.
A computer program designed to simulate conversation with human users.
Often used for customer service and information retrieval.
Powered by artificial intelligence.
An AI-powered software agent that can perform tasks or services for an individual.
Siri, Alexa, and Google Assistant are famous examples.
Can respond to voice commands.
A process of making three-dimensional solid objects from a digital file.
Uses an additive manufacturing process.
Can be used to create prototypes, tools, and art.
A device that measures unique physical or behavioral characteristics.
Used for identification and security.
Fingerprint scanners and facial recognition are examples.
A type of biometric scanner.
Used to unlock smartphones and computers.
Authenticates a person's identity based on their unique ridges.
A technology capable of identifying or verifying a person from a digital image or a video frame.
Used in phone unlocking and security systems.
A type of biometric software.
The use of unmanned aerial vehicles to transport packages.
Amazon is a company experimenting with this.
Could potentially revolutionize logistics and shipping.
A vehicle that combines an internal combustion engine with an electric motor.
The Toyota Prius is a famous example.
Uses less gasoline than a traditional car.
A vehicle that is propelled by one or more electric motors.
Tesla is the most famous company in this field.
Does not produce tailpipe emissions.
An electrochemical cell that converts chemical energy into electrical energy.
Used in some electric vehicles.
The most common type uses hydrogen as a fuel.
A device that converts sunlight into electrical energy.
Uses photovoltaic cells to generate electricity.
A key component of renewable energy systems.
A device that converts the kinetic energy of wind into electrical energy.
Has large blades that spin in the wind.
Often found in large arrays called 'wind farms'.
An electricity network that uses digital technology to monitor and manage energy transmission.
Allows for more efficient and reliable energy distribution.
A modern upgrade to traditional power grids.
A device used to initiate and control a sustained nuclear chain reaction.
Used to generate electricity in a power plant.
The first one was built by Enrico Fermi in 1942.
A boat propelled by a steam engine.
Developed in the late 18th century.
Robert Fulton's Clermont was famous for commercial use.
A device worn on the back that propels the user through the air.
The first untethered one was the Bell Rocket Belt.
Often seen in science fiction movies.
A self-balancing two-wheeled electric scooter.
Popularized in the mid-2010s.
The name comes from a science fiction movie.
A mechanical arm that is programmable.
Used for assembly lines and manufacturing.
The Unimate was an early example.
A wearable mobile machine that augments, strengthens, or restores an individual's motor skills.
Used for military, medical, and industrial applications.
A key technology in bionics.
A visual prosthesis for restoring sight to people with severe vision loss.
Uses a camera to capture images and transmit them to the brain.
Also known as a 'retinal implant'.
A type of surgery that uses a laser to cut or ablate tissue.
Used in procedures like LASIK.
Allows for more precise and less invasive procedures.
The use of 3D printing techniques to create tissue and organs.
Uses bio-inks to create structures with living cells.
A promising technology for regenerative medicine.
The process of creating genetically identical copies of an organism.
Dolly the sheep was the first mammal successfully cloned.
A controversial but significant bio-tech invention.
A medical approach that treats or prevents disease by correcting the underlying genetic problem.
Involves inserting a new gene into a patient's cells.
A promising treatment for genetic disorders.
A passport that contains a microchip with biometric data.
Stores a digital image of the passport holder's face.
Used to enhance security at border crossings.
A nanocrystal that emits a specific color of light.
Used in some television and monitor displays.
The color of light emitted depends on the size of the crystal.
The manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale.
Used in medicine, electronics, and materials science.
Involves building things from the bottom up.
An allotrope of carbon consisting of a single layer of atoms.
One of the strongest and most conductive materials known.
Discovered by Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov.
A type of light bulb that uses LEDs to produce light.
More energy-efficient and longer-lasting than incandescent bulbs.
Nick Holonyak Jr. is credited with inventing the LED.
A family of wireless network protocols.
Allows devices to connect to the internet or communicate with each other.
Invented in 1991 by NCR Corporation/AT&T.
The network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies.
Stands for 'IoT'.
Allows devices to collect and exchange data.
A mobile phone that performs many of the functions of a computer.
The first one was arguably the IBM Simon Personal Communicator.
Combines a cellular phone with a mobile operating system.
A method of exchanging digital messages.
Ray Tomlinson is credited with its invention in 1971.
Uses the '@' symbol to separate username and domain.
A satellite-based navigation system.
Owned by the US government and operated by the Space Force.
Originally known as Navstar.
An electronic circuit on a small piece of semiconductor material.
Also known as an integrated circuit.
Invented independently by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce in the late 1950s.
A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances.
Named after a 10th-century Scandinavian king.
Used for connecting headsets, speakers, and other peripherals.
An information space where documents and other web resources are identified by URLs.
Created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Often confused with the internet itself.
A computer system that emulates another computer.
Allows a single computer to run multiple operating systems.
Used extensively in cloud computing and software development.
A type of computer that uses quantum-mechanical phenomena.
Can solve certain problems much faster than classical computers.
Relies on qubits instead of bits.
A computer with a high-level computational capacity.
Used for scientific research and complex simulations.
The Cray-1 was a famous example.
A large, powerful computer used for business and scientific computing.
Known for its reliability and high processing speeds.
IBM is a major manufacturer.
A computer program or device that provides functionality for other programs or devices.
Serves data to other computers on a network.
Houses websites and other online services.
One of the first electronic general-purpose computers.
Stands for 'Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer'.
Used to calculate artillery firing tables for the US Army.
A line of electronic digital stored-program computers.
Stands for 'Universal Automatic Computer'.
The first commercial computer produced in the US.
